challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

subtopics.fact: Anyone may challenge a voter, including an observer or watcher at the polls. Any individual can enter a polling place to challenge the right of any other individual to vote.

Challenges are permitted at the polls on Election Day. However, the only ground on which a challenge can be made at the polls is a challenge to the voter's identity (i.e., that the voter is not whom he or she says he or she is).
subtopics.subtopic: What are the restrictions on polling place challenges?

subtopics.fact: The only ground on which a challenge can be made at the polls is a challenge to the voter's identity (i.e., that the voter is not whom he or she says he or she is).
subtopics.subtopic: What are the allowed reasons on which a voter can be challenged?

subtopics.fact: Someone may challenge a voter only if they have a reasonable basis for asserting that the voter is not whom the voter claims to be. Because someone challenging a voter may be required to sign a statement under penalty of perjury, the challenge to a voter's identity must be made in good faith. Someone may not arbitrarily challenge voters.
subtopics.subtopic: Is there a requirement for the challenger to provide cause or evidence?

subtopics.fact:
Once an election judge has been notified of a challenge, the election judge will ask the challenged voter to provide identification. Any of the following is an acceptable form of ID:  
  
 * Voter registration card  
  
 * Social Security card  
  
 * Valid Maryland driver's license or MVA-issued ID card  
  
 * Any ID card issued by any unit of federal, state, or local government  
  
 * Any employee ID card with the individual's photo and issued to the individual in the ordinary course of the employer's business  
  
 * A copy of a current bill, bank statement, government check, paycheck, or other government document that shows the individual's name and current address.  
  
If the individual presents one of the forms of ID listed above, the election judge must let the voter complete the check in process and vote. 

If the individual does not present one of the forms of ID, the election judge will require the person challenging the voter to provide, in writing and under penalty of perjury, the reason for the challenge and offer the challenged voter the opportunity to cast a provisional ballot and submit a signed statement, witnessed by the election judge, of his or her identity. During the provisional ballot canvass (held on the second Wednesday after the election), the local board of canvassers will determine, based on the information submitted by the individual challenging the voter and the challenged voter, whether the voter is whom he or she claims to be and is otherwise qualified to vote.
